Posts.Content: Hi Coley1993 i had a right mastectomy in October this year I also had a 21mm lump ER+ no lymphnodes involvement. My Oncotype score came back at 32 so I’m having adjuvant chemo but a slightly different regime to yourself. I’m having 12 cycles of Paclitaxel weekly (had number 5 today) and fortunately very little in the way of side effects apart from tiredness. I’m also due to have 3 cycles of EC once the Packitaxel finishes.  My chemo is preventative too. I’ve not used cold cap and my hair has come out so I made the decision to cut it right down and felt much better once I had done that and I have a lovely wig I’m so sorry to hear you are finding chemo hard going. I did ask the question if I didn’t or couldn’t finish my chemo whether it would have any benefit but they couldn’t really give me a clear answer. It might be worth talking to your Oncologist to see if they could perhaps change you to an alternative chemo that might give you less side effects - they did say to me that would be an option if I was finding it difficulties to tolerate it for any reason. Your Oncotype score is low so there could be other options for you. I will be going back on Letrozole for 5-10 years once my chemo has finished.  Sending you hugs   Lynn xx
Posts.Title: ***December 2018 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat ***

Posts.Content: Thinking of you tomorrow TheScriptFan hope all goes well for you   Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Reconstruction using back muscle, anyone else??

Posts.Content: Hi silversilver  I bought a Braun digital ear thermometer from Boots and was also given a basic thermometer by the Hospital. Both give the same readings but I prefer the digital one.  Lynn x
Posts.Title: ***April 2019 Breast Cancer Chemo Chat***

Posts.Content: Hello Georgia78 I found myself in a very similar situation to yourself. I found a lump just before a family holiday last September - had a mastectomy (my choice) with no spread to my lymphnodes but had the Oncotype DX test which showed I was at high risk of recurrence and this was a huge shock. I was advised chemotherapy to prevent it coming back and started chemo on 28 November. I’ve just completed 12 weekly cycles of Paclitaxel which was doable - I did have some rubbish days but I did manage to get out most days as normal  - I got tired but coped. Just had my first EC (3x3 weekly cycles) which has hit me harder and I’ve had a couple of days where I’ve felt wiped out but just rested but is doable and like you I will throw everything at it to prevent it coming back in the future.  What chemo have they advised? Be guided by your body rest when you need to - take all the anti sickness tablets they give you before you feel sick as it’s much easier to control before you start to feel sick.  Everyone is different and you can do this and the time goes surprisingly quickly once you start.  Sending you lots of hugs   Lynn xx
Posts.Title: About to start my chemo journey

Posts.Content: Hi Georgia78  I decided not to cold cap for the reason you said about the time it adds on and I do suffer with headaches so decided against it but a few ladies that I’ve met have done it and with good results. You can always give it a go and it it’s not for you then there’s nothing lost. I bought lots of hats and have a lovely wig and it’s great being able to get ready in a matter of minutes! Losing my hair was one of the hardest things for me but to be honest it hasn’t been as bad as I thought it would be - once it started coming out I took the decision to shave it down to a number 2 (hubby did it Christmas Eve) and I’ve never completely lost it and in fact it has started to grow a little bit but I think it will all go with my next cycle of treatment.  They will go through everything with you at your pre chemo chat and the nurses are just so lovely and reassuring and will answer all your questions. I took a notebook with me and wrote everything down - there is so much to remember. I also invested in a digital thermometer which has been worth every penny.  Big hugs   Lynn xx
Posts.Title: About to start my chemo journey

Posts.Content: Bustysusy  I was terrified of losing my hair at the beginning but when it started to come out we shaved it off and everyone said how good I looked and I actually like it now! I’ve got a lovely wig which I do wear too but losing my hair wasn’t as bad as I thought it would be. Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Last chemo done

Posts.Content: I’ve had my last chemo today it’s been a long journey but finally over and I can look forward now. A very emotional day. I still don’t think my diagnosis has fully hit me and it will feel strange not being on the hospital appointment treadmill. I’m looking forward to building my strength back up and getting back to the gym in June. Also looking forward to 2 more grandchildren expected in June! Good luck to everyone starting or still having treatment Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Last chemo done

Posts.Content: Weeblemum Thank you! Planning a celebratory meal with the family in a couple of weeks when the injections and steroids are done hopefully with a G&T! Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Last chemo done

Posts.Content: Bustysusy  What a great pic! It is the most amazing feeling Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Last chemo done

Posts.Content: Hi Rumcat Thats good that you know - you will feel better when you have your plan in place it’s the uncertainty and not knowing that is the worst thing  good luck and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Hi from a Newbie

Posts.Content: Hi Rumcat Thats good that you know - you will feel better when you have your plan in place it’s the uncertainty and not knowing that is the worst thing  good luck and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Hi from a Newbie

Posts.Content: Hi Rum Cat So sorry you find yourself here but you will receive lots of support and good advice.  I found a lump 24 August and was seen urgently 31 August I had a biopsy and returned for my results 10 September (they had already told me it was malignant). I too had a long planned holiday booked to Australia and Dubai on the 22nd September. My results came back as ER positive and I was started on Letrozole that day and told I could go on my holiday and was given a date for surgery on my return for the 11th October. We had very mixed feelings about going away but am glad that we went even though it was always at the back of my mind but I knew the Letrozole was doing it’s job. It will depend on your results and your consultant will guide you as what is best for you. I hope all goes well for you.  Love and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Hi from a Newbie

Posts.Content: Hi Rum Cat So sorry you find yourself here but you will receive lots of support and good advice.  I found a lump 24 August and was seen urgently 31 August I had a biopsy and returned for my results 10 September (they had already told me it was malignant). I too had a long planned holiday booked to Australia and Dubai on the 22nd September. My results came back as ER positive and I was started on Letrozole that day and told I could go on my holiday and was given a date for surgery on my return for the 11th October. We had very mixed feelings about going away but am glad that we went even though it was always at the back of my mind but I knew the Letrozole was doing it’s job. It will depend on your results and your consultant will guide you as what is best for you. I hope all goes well for you.  Love and hugs xx
Posts.Title: Hi from a Newbie

Posts.Content: Hi everyone  I had my third Paclitaxel today and have had very few side effects up to now thankfully a bit of an upset tummy after first one and just felt more tired but otherwise okay and my hair is hanging on! I think it will go this weekend but I’m much more prepared for it now i saw the Oncologist today and she wants me to have Zolendronate next week alongside my chemo (every 6 months for 3 years) and I’ve done my homework and agreed to go ahead. The side effects sound pretty rubbish but let’s face it all side effects do and you don’t always get them. Has anyone had Zolendronate with their chemo and what was it like. I’ve been advised to take Paracetamol and Ibuprofen the day before to help with any aches and pains and my Dentist has given me the go ahead.  Thanks - Lynn xx
Posts.Title: Starting Zolendronate

Posts.Content: Thanks Sandy that’s very reassuring I’m keeping positive that I’ll be okay - the chemo up to now hasn’t been as bad as I expected so hopefully the Zolendronate won’t be either  lynn xx
Posts.Title: Starting Zolendronate

Posts.Content: Thank you!  I’m starting on Paclitaxel once a week for 12 weeks which apparently is tolerable (I hope) and then EC chemo (epirubicin and cyclophosphamide) once a week every 3 weeks which sounds yuk They are happy the surgery has removed all the cancer and my lymphnodes are clear but because my score puts me in the high risk category of recurrence it will improve my chances of any recurrence I’m dreading losing my hair and wondering about trying the cold cap I’m not looking forward to the next 6 months well done on finishing your chemo  xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo

Posts.Content: hi everyone  I’ve seen the oncologist and am going to start chemo 28 November as it is going to significantly improve my chances of risk of recurrence. My score was 32 so just into the high risk category. I’m terrified but feel I’m doing the right thing and that it’s best for me - I will have once weekly chemo for 12 weeks then 2 drugs once weekly every 3 weeks and hopefully any stray cells that might be lurking will be zapped.  Xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo

Posts.Content: Looking forward to pink wee! Yes I will get a voucher from the hospital for a wig and my lovely hairdresser has already said she will cut it for me if needed - it could be nice having a different look! I’ll think about the cold cap and might try but if I can’t tolerate it I’m not going to worry and there are lovely hats scarfs and bandanas to wear too.  Do you know how long it takes for your hair to start to grow back? Its fear of the unknown but I have a couple of friends who have been through chemo and they are very supportive too. My family are amazing too so I’m very fortunate and it’s so good to be able to talk to people here who are going through this or have been through it Xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you so much for sharing your photos and you look beautiful on both pics and I feel less scared now about losing my hair Big hugs xxx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo

Posts.Content: I’ll make sure I drink plenty water - my lovely breast nurse has mentioned that to me and I use Aussie shampoo so will make sure I stock up ready. Thanks for the tips  Xx
Posts.Title: Oncotype results and chemo
